awd_titl_txt: Structure and Electronic Anomalies of Amorphous Chalcogenides
awd_abstract_narration:
Vassiliy Lubchenko of the University of Houston is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry division to develop a theoretical and computational approach to studying an important class of inorganic solids, called the "chalcogenides," that contain elements from groups XVI (sulfur, selenium, tellurium), XV (phosphorus, arsenic, antimony, bismuth), and XIV (germanium).  The ability of these solids to switch readily between ordered crystalline and amorphous ("glassy") forms allows one to tune the optical and electronic properties of these materials in an efficient way.  This property makes the chalcogenides prime candidates for applications in optical drives, next generation computer memory and displays, smart optics, and novel computer architectures Amorphous chalcogenides are a special type of disordered solids called "glasses," which are ordinarily made by rapidly cooling a liquid, usually below its melting point   One can convert a chalcogenide alloy between the glass and  ordered crystalline form by first melting the material and, then, cooling the melt at a specified rate.  Slow cooling yields the crystal, fast cooling yields the glass.  The present study is establishing detailed connections between the molecular motions underlying the glass transition and quantum-chemical interactions in the chalcogenide alloys.  Direct molecular modeling of the glass transition is difficult and is part of the greater challenge of predicting the structure of complex inorganic solids and designing materials with tailored properties.   The study is exploiting the similarity of the interplay between distinct chemical interactions in the chalcogenides and the behavior of a well-defined model of mathematical physics to make the problem tractable.  At the center of the broader impact activities is training of graduate, undergraduate, and, in particular, high school students.  A strategy is in place to ensure the participating high school and undergraduate students complete meaningful subprojects that will contribute to peer-reviewed publications.


The microscopic hypothesis of the proposed work is that the glass-forming ability of the chalcogenide alloys stems from a competition between distinct types of chemical bonding: covalent, multicenter, and secondary.  The resulting complex interplay of interactions is captured by a classic model of statistical physics, viz., the 64-vertex model, which is being implemented.  The most important outputs of the calculation are the structure and the configurational entropy of amorphous chalcogenides.  The configurational entropy determines the complexity of the free energy landscape of the alloys and their glass-forming ability.  To back up these calculations, a novel procedure is being implemented for generating dense glassy structures for particles with distorted-octahedral bonding typical of the chalcogenides.  An additional coarse-graining description is being implemented with the help of a recently developed 6-component spin model based on the theory of elasticity of structurally-degenerate solids.

por.por_cntn:
These studies centered on several puzzling properties of an important class of inorganic solids, called the "chalcogenides," that contain elements from groups XVI (sulfur, selenium, tellurium), XV (phosphorus, arsenic, antimony, bismuth), and XIV (germanium). The ability of these solids to switch readily between ordered-crystalline and amorphous ("glassy") forms allows one to tune the optical and electronic properties of these materials in an efficient way. Thus the chalcogenides are prime candidates for applications in optical drives, next generation computer memory and displays, smart optics, and novel computer architectures. When in amorphous state, the chalcogenides represent a special type of disordered solids called "glasses," which are ordinarily made by rapidly cooling a liquid, usually below its melting point.

The chalcogenides epitomize several outstanding problems of Chemistry and Physics. On the one hand, individual atoms comprising these fascinating compounds each show distinct bonding patterns despite being chemically equivalent. How this diversity of bonding emerges on its own is difficult to understand in view of the rather limited variety of bonding patterns these elements exhibit in small molecules or crystalline solids. This challenge is part of the greater problem of the molecular origin of the glass transition and, also, underlies our inability to predict very basic properties of solids such as their structure and melting points. In the case of the chalcogenides and similar compounds, Mother Nature seems to ?rub it in? even further: Diffraction patterns produced by these alloys show a feature that is not representative or the network formed by the chemical bonds. This feature corresponds to a length scale that is a few multiples of the interatomic distance and is called the first sharp diffraction peak; its origin has been debated for decades. Amorphous chalcogenides do not readily conduct electrical current because of a seeming lack of orbitals where electrons can be thermally excited. For the same reason, these alloys are not supposed to absorb light in the green-red color range. But they do begin to absorb such light after having been exposed to intense blue light, presumably because this light activates mysterious electronic states at forbidden values of energy. This problem has evaded a first principles understanding since the 1970s. Directly attacking these problems, using quantum chemical methodologies, however runs into difficulties because present day computers, though very powerful, would have to run for astronomical times to mimic the gradual cooling schedules used to make chalcogenides in the lab.

We have partially circumvented these difficulties by designing and implementing a novel structure-building algorithm that uses those quantum-chemical methodologies only for the final refinement of the structure. The so obtained structures turned out to exhibit both the first sharp diffraction peak and the mysterious electronic states in the forbidden energy range! We have established that the puzzling diversity of bonding patterns exhibited by individual atoms has a very rich and profound origin: This diversity emerges as an interplay between distinct types of chemical bonding that had been postulated by chemists for over a century. We have shown that these types of bonding can be indeed systematically described as distinct phases of the electronic liquid, not unlike the vapor, liquid, and solid phases of matter. Here, instead, the control parameters are not pressure and temperature, but the atomic density, the spatial variation in electronegativity, and the disparity in the atomic size. We took these notions further to connect the properties of the electronic fluid, when it is ?frozen? inside an electrical insulator, with the symmetry of the underlying lattice. The connection is through the so-called optical phonons and, as we have established, explains a surprisingly strong dependence of the insulating gap on temperature in the chalcogenides and, in fact, most insulating solids. (The optical phonons correspond with lattice vibrations such that have to do with the mutual distance between close-by neighbors and do not lead to significant density changes.) A remarkable outcome of this result is that solids composed of a single chemical element that exhibit certain, very common lattice types that do not allow for optical phonons must be metallic! The listed results form a foundation for our ongoing investigations into the behaviors of the electronic fluid and its interplay with the lattice.

At the center of the broader impact activities was training of graduate, undergraduate, and, in particular, high school students. The involved high school students have been exposed to and learned advanced methods of theoretical chemistry at a level that could not be realized in a normal setting. An undergraduate student, who is now pursuing an advanced degree in medicine, co-authored a peer-reviewed article, while several high school students have entered premier undergraduate institutions in STEM fields.
